Two stockholders have gone to court to block the proposed $1.4 billion merger of two big software companies, the Lotus Development Corporation and Novell Inc., the companies said yesterday.
Delaware Chancery Court seeks an injunction against the proposed merger, which sent shares of both companies tumbling after it was announced last week.

Maskaleris and Herbert Podell, two Novell shareholders, contends that Novell and its directors breached their fiduciary duties to shareholders in agreeing to merge with Lotus. Lotus, which is issuing new stock to acquire Novell, was named as a defendant for abetting Novell in its actions.
Novell said the companies believe the suit is without merit. They did not say when the lawsuit was filed.
Lotus, whose personal computer spreadsheets dominate the market, announced its plan last week for the biggest merger ever in the personal computer software business.

The combined companies would have sales of about $1 billion, making the resulting entity almost as big as the Microsoft Corporation, the industry leader, whose sales this year are expected to top $1 billion.
